text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new drones LP I see seaweed the
drones are an Australian rock outfit
they've been at it for well over ten
years now and they have about ten studio
and live albums under their belts to
show for it as well as an Australian
music prize which they won in 2005
thanks to one of their full lengths and
this band's earliest material had a
really rough and wild garage rock and
blues punk sound but they eventually
kind of mellowed out on later releases
such as Gala mill even though the drones
have shown some real progression over
the course of their career they're not
really in the same spot they used to be
the roots of the band are still very
much intact because that punk blues
garage rock sound rings in really true
on one track on here a moat you can
stand in which is this four-minute
barnburner manic vocals pounding piano
chords the track is hard as nails it's
like the amplifiers are on fire once
they kind of get into this interlude I
guess you could say it's a whole lot of
noise really it's at points like this
that the energy that this band displays
as well as the just the very snide
vocals the blaring guitars fans of other
Aussie garage rock acts like eddy
current suppression ring could totally
get into what this album has to offer
but the slower tracks on here that are a
little more dismal with a lot of sullen
vocals and very dark gloomy narratives
people who are totally in the Nick Cave
may be a little bit of PJ Harvey could
enjoy this album as well most the other
songs on this LP might not be as
cutthroat but they kind of display their
intensity in other ways through a lot of
angry sad and sometimes hopeless
feelings and to build on top of that the
songs on this album which are very good
are typically really expansive sitting
within that six to nine minute mark and
though I do think a lot of these tracks
are interesting instrumentally
throughout it's really the band's
frontman Gareth lyddiard that keeps me
sitting on the edge of my seat listening
to the words he's saying and listening
to his very emotive
dramatic and sometimes over-the-top
vocal delivery different tracks on this
Opie have different feels to them like
the opener on this album the title track
I see seaweed which really to me kind of
feels like this dark very eerie ominous
start to the entire album it's like
listening to a storyteller warn the
listener warn the traveler that you're
about to embark upon a very dark
adventure very shy pianos and guitars
make dramatic sounds behind Gareth's
vocals just increasing the intensity and
the tension of the story he's telling
which has imagery of stepping into our
swamp and the chorus on this track is
just explosive it's bombs it's the storm
that the verses were forecasting again
the band has a real appreciation for
instrumental dynamics huge spots small
spots subtle intros giant climaxes it's
to the point where shorter songs on this

see through fog while I did like this
track is a hook to initially listen to
this LP it just feels like a morsel

monolithic and intense songs on this

exciting as other songs on this album
and emotionally and sonically they're
spots on here like they'll kill you
which are very explosive but the tune is
just not there the vocals melodically

at all thankfully these two tracks are
like the biggest missteps on the LP
after these songs the track the gray

emotionally potent ballad in three
things just feels so rickety they feel
so noisy they feel like they're just

sort of clean up in a way after this

in the dumps song and it feels in a way

he feels so hopeless at this point in

singing about how people don't really

it's it's more depressing than what I'm
